title: Creating a reading list on argument quality assessment involves selecting articles that cover various aspects of the topic, including theoretical foundations, methodologies, applications, and recent advancements. Hereâ€™s a list of 20 articles that you might find useful
This book provides a comprehensive overview of argument evaluation, focusing on evidence and its role in assessing argument quality

publisher: *The Uses of Argument.* Cambridge University Press

title: A classic work that introduces the Toulmin model of argumentation, which is fundamental for understanding argument structure and quality

publisher: Software for Puzzles in Argument Diagramming and XML.*

title: Discusses a tool for argument diagramming, which is crucial for visualizing and assessing argument quality
Offers insights into identifying and evaluating arguments, focusing on logical fallacies and argument strength
*A Systematic Theory of Argumentation: The Pragma-Dialectical Approach.*
Introduces a framework for analyzing and evaluating arguments based on dialectical principles
A practical guide to understanding and evaluating arguments, with a focus on real-world applications
*Which Argument is More Convincing?
container-title: Analyzing and Predicting Convincingness of Web Arguments.* Proceedings of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Explores computational methods for assessing the convincingness of arguments found online
*Speech Acts of Argumentation
container-title: Inference Anchors and Peripheral Cues in Dialogue.* Proceedings of the International Conference on Computational Models of Argument

title: Examines the role of speech acts in argumentation and their impact on argument quality
*Evaluating Arguments and Making Meta-Arguments.* Argumentation
Discusses the process of evaluating arguments and constructing meta-arguments to assess argument quality

container-title: *Classifying Arguments by Scheme.* Proceedings of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Focuses on classifying arguments based on argumentation schemes, which is essential for quality assessment
*Argument Mining: A Survey.* Computational Linguistics
Provides a comprehensive overview of argument mining techniques, which are crucial for automated argument quality assessment
*From Argument Diagrams to Argumentation Mining in Texts: A Survey.*
container-title: International Journal of Cognitive Informatics and Natural Intelligence

title: Surveys methods for extracting and evaluating arguments from text, highlighting challenges and opportunities
*Show Me Your Evidence
container-title: Automatic Argumentation Mining from Heterogeneous Sources.* Proceedings of the Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Discusses techniques for mining and evaluating arguments from diverse sources, focusing on evidence quality
*Argumentation Quality Assessment: Theory vs
container-title: Practice.* Proceedings of the Conference on Computational Models of Argument

title: Compares theoretical approaches to argument quality assessment with practical applications

container-title: *Legal Argumentation and Evidence.* Artificial Intelligence and Law

title: Explores the assessment of argument quality in legal contexts, emphasizing evidence and reasoning
*Back up Your Stance
container-title: Recognizing Arguments in Online Discussions.* Proceedings of the First Workshop on Argumentation Mining

title: Investigates methods for identifying and evaluating arguments in online discussions
*Argument Mining in the Wild
container-title: The Annotation and Detection of Implicit Claims in Text.* Proceedings of the Conference on Computational Models of Argument

title: Focuses on detecting implicit claims in text, which is a key aspect of argument quality assessment

container-title: *Identifying Argumentation Schemes in Genetics Research Articles.* Proceedings of the Conference on Computational Models of Argument

title: Examines the use of argumentation schemes in scientific articles, highlighting their role in assessing argument quality

container-title: *Identifying Appropriate Support for Propositions in Online User Comments.* Proceedings of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Discusses methods for evaluating the support provided for propositions in online comments

container-title: *Recognizing Insufficiently Supported Arguments in Argumentative Essays.* Transactions of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Focuses on identifying and evaluating unsupported arguments in essays, contributing to automated quality assessment
These articles cover a range of topics related to argument quality assessment, from theoretical frameworks to practical applications and computational methods
